questions.text: Which of the following is used in immunohistochemical (IHC) staining as a chromogen to diagnose tumours of unknown origin?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Diaminobenzidine

Explanation:

3,3′ Diaminobenzidine (DAB) is a chromogen used in histochemical and IHC staining.

  • In IHC, DAB is a substrate for a peroxidase enzyme coupled to a primary or secondary antibody.
  • It is oxidised and converted to an insoluble polymer, precipitating as a dark brown pigment, which allows visualisation of the target molecule.

 

Congo red can stain (Option B) amyloid fibres in red and orange. When viewed under polarised light in a microscope, Congo-red-stained tissues high in amyloid will show bright apple-green birefringence (Option 2).

Masson's Trichrome stain (Option C) is a three-color stain that highlights collagen in blue, muscle in red, and nuclei in blue-black. It helps identify fibrosis in the heart, lungs, and kidney.

Mucicarmine stains (Option D) mucin, a secretion produced in epithelial and connective tissue and capsule of Cryptococcus.

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker for breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 3) CA-15-3

Explanation:

CA-15-3 is the tumour marker seen in breast cancer.

Tumor marker

Associated conditions

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

 
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Yolk sac tumour (endodermal sinus tumour)
  • Nonseminomatous germ cell tumour of testis
  • ↑ AFP: abdominal wall defects, neural tube defects
  • ↓ AFP: associated with trisomy 21, 18, and 13 

β-HCG

(Option D ruled out)

 
  • Nonseminomatous testicular germ cell tumours (choriocarcinoma, embryonal cell carcinoma, mixed germ cell tumour, seminoma)
  • Ovarian cancer: choriocarcinoma (gestational trophoblastic disease)

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
  • Colorectal cancer
  • Pancreatic cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Lung cancer (especially in non-small cell cancers)
  • Gastric cancer

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA)
  • Prostate cancer
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • Prostatitis

Calcitonin
  • Medullary thyroid cancer (both sporadic and associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2)

Alkaline phosphatase
  • Metastases to bone or liver
  • Paget disease of the bone

Placental alkaline phosphatase
  • Seminoma

Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Ovarian cancer (dysgerminoma)
  • Testicular germ cell tumours (both seminoma and nonseminoma)
  • Lymphomas
  • Ewing's sarcoma

Neuron specific enolase (NSE)
  • Neuroendocrine tumors
  • Small cell lung cancer
  • Carcinoid tumour
  • Neuroblastoma

CA 19–9

(Option A ruled out)
  • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma
  • Colon cancer
  • Cholangiocarcinoma

CA 15–3 and CA 27–29

(Option C)
  • Breast cancer

CA 125

(Option B ruled out)
  • Ovarian carcinoma
  • Other gynecologic malignancies

S-100 protein (S100A) and (S100B)
  • Malignant melanoma

SMRP
  • Mesothelioma

questions.text: Which of the following is used to determine treatment response in patients with colorectal cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Carcinoembryogenic antigen

Explanation:

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) can be used to assess responsiveness to treatment in colorectal cancers.

  • Persistent elevation of CEA after successful tumor resection suggests residual or recurrent disease and warrants further investigation.
  • It is associated with the following cancers: (Mnemonic: C KaPiL SHarma)
    • C - CEA
    • K - Colon cancer
    • P - Pancreatic cancer
    • L - Lung cancer
    • S - Stomach cancer
    • H - Heart tumors

Alpha-fetoprotein (Option A) is associated with yolk sac tumours and hepatic tumors (hepatocellular carcinoma, hepatoblastoma).

Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (Option C) is elevated in choriocarcinoma and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

Calcitonin (Option D) is a tumor marker for Medullary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: What needle size is typically employed for Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) procedures?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 3) 25-gauge needle

Explanation:

The appropriate needle size commonly used for FNAC procedures is the 25-27-gauge needle. 

  • It is a minimally invasive technique for procuring cells from suspicious lesions or masses for cytological examination. It utilises a slender needle gauge to extract cells from the target site.
  • The lesion of interest is identified via imaging modalities (ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI).
  • A needle is inserted into the lesion, and gentle suction is applied to draw cells into a syringe.
  • Multiple passes may be made to ensure a sufficient sample volume.
  • The material is either smeared onto glass slides or preserved in a fixative solution for subsequent cytological analysis.
  • The 25–27-gauge needle is commonly used for FNAC, providing effective sample collection while minimizing discomfort and tissue damage.
    • Thinner needles may be preferred for organs surrounded by critical structures (thyroid gland) to reduce the risk of complications.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is FNAC helpful in establishing diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

Explanation:

FNAC serves as an initial diagnostic tool for medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), often revealing pinkish amyloid material alongside malignant cells—findings that are highly suggestive of MTC.

Limitations of FNAC:

  • Cystic changes cannot be identified.
  • Inadequate cell sampling may require repeated procedure

Indications

Contraindications /limitations

Thyroid disorders

Follicular disorders of the thyroid (Limitation) (Option A ruled out)

Breast lesions

Infections, septicemia

Lymph node evaluation

Bleeding disorders

Pancreatic malignancy

Hydatid cyst- Risk of anaphylaxis

(Option C ruled out)

Most solid organ masses accessible via FNAC

Testicular cancer- Increased risk of spread of cancer

(Option B ruled out)

Follicular adenoma of the thyroid (Option A): FNAC cannot definitively diagnose follicular neoplasms, as the key distinction between benign and malignant forms lies in detecting capsular and vascular invasion. This assessment isn't possible with FNAC, as the thin needle doesn't allow evaluation of tissue architecture.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a breast lump. On biopsy, the tissue shows anaplastic cells without any differentiation. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining is performed to characterise the tumour further. Which marker would be most appropriate to confirm the epithelial origin of the tumour cells in breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) CK7

Explanation:

In a female with a breast lump and presence of anaplastic cells, CK7 (cytokeratin 7) is the most appropriate marker to confirm the epithelial origin of the tumor, as cytokeratins are commonly expressed in all carcinomas.

  • In Immunohistochemistry (IHC), a CK7 and CK20 profile is commonly used to help determine the tumor origin.

  • Most female-origin cancers (breast, endometrial, thyroid, cervical) typically show a CK7-positive and CK20-negative pattern. (Option D)

  • ER (estrogen receptor), PR (progesterone receptor), and HER2 (human epidermal growth factor receptor 2) are other markers that can be positive in breast cancer, which help in deciding management.

 

CD20 (Option A) is a B-cell marker that is typically positive in B-cell lymphomas, including non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL).

Pp3 (Option B) is a marker positive in squamous cell carcinoma in the lung.

TTF-1(thyroid transcription factor-1) (Option D) is a marker positive in the adenocarcinoma of the lung.

questions.text:
Match the given neoplasias with their respective immunohistochemistry markers.


 


	
		
			
			1. Carcinoma
			
			
			A. S100
			
		
		
			
			2. Sarcoma
			
			
			B. Leucocyte common antigen
			
		
		
			
			3. Lymphoma
			
			
			C. Cytokeratin
			
		
		
			
			4. Melanoma
			
			
			D. Vimentin
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

Explanation:

The correctly matched pair of neoplasias and their respective immunohistochemistry(IHC) markers are:

 

Carcinoma

(epithelial origin/squamous cell carcinoma)

Cytokeratin

Cytokeratin 1, cytokeratin 10

Sarcoma

Vimentin, desmin(skeletal muscle)

Lymphoma

Leucocyte common antigen, CD 45

Melanoma

S100, HMB45, Melan A

questions.text: A 60-year-old male was diagnosed with a lung malignancy two months ago. He now came with complaints of malaise, abdominal pain, bone pain, lethargy, and confusion. The intern suspects a condition related to lung cancer and decides to send a blood test. Which of the following would be the appropriate test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Parathyroid hormone-related protein

Explanation:

The clinical scenario indicates paraneoplastic hypercalcemia likely linked to lung cancer, and the appropriate diagnostic test is parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP).

 

Paraneoplastic syndrome: 

  • Refers to signs and symptoms that cannot be explained by the tumour's anatomic distribution or hormones indigenous to the tumour tissue.
  • These occur in about 10% of patients with cancer
  • It may be the earliest manifestation of an occult neoplasm.
  • It may mimic metastatic disease and confound treatment.
  • PTHRP leads to hypercalcemia, which can present as
    • Nausea, vomiting,
    • Abdominal pain (groans),
    • Bone pain (bones),
    • Renal stones (stones),
    • Fatigue malaise (moans),
    • Polyuria, polydipsia,
    • Constipation (thrones),
    • Lethargy, confusion, depression,
    • Memory loss (psychic overtones).
  • PTHRP is also associated with
    • Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung
    • Breast carcinoma
    • Renal carcinoma
    • Adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma


Erythropoietin (Option A) levels can be checked in polycythemia, which associated with renal carcinoma, cerebellar hemangioma, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Adrenocorticotropic hormone(ACTH) (Option B) levels can be checked in Cushing’s syndrome which is associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung, pancreatic carcinoma, and neural tumours.

Antidiuretic hormone (Option D) levels can be checked in Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion(SIADH) which is associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung and intracranial neoplasms.

questions.text: Which of the following paraneoplastic syndrome is not associated with lung cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Red cell aplasia

Explanation:

Red cell aplasia is associated with thymic neoplasms and not lung cancer.

  • Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with lung cancer are as follows:

Cushing syndrome

Small cell carcinoma of the lung, Pancreatic tumours

SIADH

Small cell carcinoma of the lung

Hypercalcemia

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung

Myasthenia (Lambert-Eaton) (Option C)

Bronchogenic carcinoma

Acanthosis nigricans (Option B)

Adenocarcinoma lung

Dermatomyositis (Option A)

Bronchogenic carcinoma

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy

and clubbing of the fingers

Adenocarcinoma lung

Venous thrombosis (Trousseau

phenomenon

Pancreatic carcinoma, Bronchogenic carcinoma

questions.text: An appendix specimen, whose HPE is shown below, had a 2 cm submucosal nodule identified. Electron microscopy showed numerous neurosecretory granules in the cytoplasm. Twenty-four-hour urine analysis showed an elevation of 5-hydroxy indoleacetic acid (5-HIAA). Which of the following would not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Bronchodilation

Explanation:

A submucosal nodule with neurosecretory granules on electron microscopy and elevated 5-HIAA confirms a neuroendocrine (carcinoid) tumor of the appendix, typically at the tip, and it is not associated with bronchodilation

Image showing cells arranged in the form of a rosette (cells in nests)

Image showing salt and pepper chromatin

Carcinoid tumors:

  • Derived from Argentaffin cells that secrete serotonin. It is commonly caused by neuroendocrine tumours of the midgut that metastasise to the liver. It is also seen with ovarian tumours or bronchial carcinoids. They secrete mediators like serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine), kallikrein, bradykinin, histamine, and prostaglandins.
  • These mediators are usually metabolised by the liver, so patients are initially asymptomatic.
  • Clinical features: (Mnemonic - SHIVA)
    • S - Systemic fibrosis
    • H - Hepatomegaly, Heart disorders (valvular heart disorders - tricuspid regurgitation) (Option C ruled out)
    • I - Intestinal motility increases (diarrhoea, abdominal cramping) (Option B ruled out)
    • V - Vasodilation (flushing, pruritus) (Option A ruled out)
    • A - Asthma-like features - wheezing, dyspnea (bronchoconstriction) (Option D) 
  • Microscopy of neuroendocrine tumors: 
    • ​​​​​​​Light microscopy: Nesting pattern
    • Electron microscopy: Neurosecretory granules.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Elevated twenty-four-hour urine for 5-HIAA
    • Elevated serum serotonin
    • Elevated serum chromogranin A
    • Octreoscan for localising the source.
